subject: Re: JUnit4 and eclipse
msgSnippet: Thanks, I now understand I did some mixed junit versions test. So I want to use JUnit4, but I am not succeding at that. I have the code as you wrote, I am
messageBody:
Thanks, I now understand I did some mixed junit versions test.
So I want to use JUnit4, but I am not succeding at that.
I have the code as you wrote, I am trying to do Run... to
multiAttacherTest.
There I can choose JUnit and under the test tab, there is Test class
box, but in the search no class appears.
How do I run a test on multiAttacherTest with junit4?

Thank you,
Ofer.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Lasse Koskela" <lasse.koskela@...>
wrote:
>
> Ofer,
>
> On 7/17/07, oferstu <oferstu@...> wrote:
> > import junit.framework.TestCase;
> > import junit.textui.TestRunner;
> > import org.junit.Test;
>
> You need to decide whether you're going to use JUnit 3.x or JUnit
4.x
> API. If you're running on Java 5, I heartily recommend JUnit 4.
> Otherwise, your only option is JUnit 3.x.
>
>
> On 7/17/07, oferstu <oferstu@...> wrote:
> > public class MultiAttacherTest extends TestCase {
> >
> > @Test public final void strongComponenetWalk() {
> > assertNull (null);
> > }
> > public static void main(String[] args) {
> > TestRunner.run (MultiAttacherTest.class);
> > }
> > }
> >
> > I get this run time error:
> > .F
> > Time: 0
> > There was 1 failure:
> > 1) warning(junit.framework.TestSuite$1)
> > junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: No tests found in
> > graph.MultiAttacherTest
> > at graph.MultiAttacherTest.main(MultiAttacherTest.java:51)
> >
> > FAILURES!!!
> > Tests run: 1, Failures: 1, Errors: 0
> >
> > If I add test in front of the method name, then it works. But
this
> > is the syntax of JUnit3, isnt it? It should have worked with the
> > code above?
> > Also, if I have a method with @Before annotation, then it won't
run
> > when I run the test.
>
> The behavior you're seeing is because you're running the test with
a
> JUnit 3.8 test runner. Try converting your test to follow the
JUnit 4
> API by getting rid of the "junit.framework" imports:
>
> import static org.junit.Assert.assertNull;
> import org.junit.Test;
>
> public class MultiAttacherTest {
> @Test
> public final void strongComponentWalk() {
> assertNull(null);
> }
> }
>
>
> Regards,
> Lasse
>
> --
> Lasse Koskela
> * Author of "Test Driven" (Manning Publications, 2007) *
> * Reaktor Innovations * http://www.ri.fi/en *
>
